content.description: Binge Eating Disorder (BED) is characterized by recurrent episodes of eating an objectively large amount of food in a discrete period, accompanied by a sense of loss of control, and associated with marked distress. Unlike bulimia nervosa, BED does not involve regular inappropriate compensatory behaviors (e.g., purging, excessive exercise).
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Recurrent episodes of binge eating, defined as: 1) eating, in a discrete period (e.g., within any 2-hour period), an amount of food that is definitely larger than most people would eat under similar circumstances; and 2) a sense of lack of control over eating during the episode. B. Episodes are associated with ≥3 of: eating more rapidly than normal; eating until uncomfortably full; eating large amounts when not physically hungry; eating alone due to embarrassment; feeling disgusted, depressed, or very guilty afterward. C. Marked distress regarding binge eating. D. Occurs, on average, at least once a week for 3 months. E. Not associated with regular use of inappropriate compensatory behaviors and does not occur exclusively during anorexia nervosa or bulimia nervosa.
content.prevalence: Estimated lifetime prevalence ~2–3% in the general population; more common in females, but also prevalent in males. Frequently comorbid with obesity, metabolic syndrome, and mood disorders.
content.age_of_onset: Typically late adolescence to early adulthood; can emerge in childhood or later adulthood.
content.prognosis: Good recovery rates with evidence-based psychotherapy; relapse possible, especially under stress. Chronic untreated BED can lead to medical complications and worsened mental health outcomes.

circuitry: Hyperactivation of mesolimbic reward pathways (ventral striatum, nucleus accumbens) to food cues.
Reduced prefrontal inhibitory control during high-calorie food exposure.
Altered hypothalamic–gut–brain signaling (ghrelin, leptin, insulin resistance).
neurotransmitters: Serotonin involvement in satiety and mood regulation.
Endogenous opioid system activation during binge episodes.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Family history of mood disorders, obesity, or substance use increases risk; adverse childhood experiences and chronic dieting contribute.

history_psychosocial: Binge episode frequency, triggers, and loss-of-control experiences.
Body image concerns, emotional eating patterns, and comorbid mental health symptoms.
medical_assessment: Weight, BMI, waist circumference, blood pressure.
Screen for metabolic syndrome: fasting glucose, lipid panel, HbA1c.
Assess for sleep apnea, GERD, musculoskeletal pain.
standardized_measures: Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) and Generalized Anxiety Disorder scale (GAD-7)
risk_stratification: Identify severe depression, suicidality, or comorbid substance use.
Assess medical risk from obesity-related conditions.
differential_diagnosis: Bulimia Nervosa (presence of regular compensatory behaviors)
Depression with hyperphagia (without discrete binge episodes)
evaluation.team_and_process: Collaborative approach with therapist, dietitian, and medical provider; include psychiatry when considering pharmacotherapy.

behavioral: Eating large amounts of food quickly, even when not hungry.
Eating alone due to shame or embarrassment.
Frequent dieting without sustained weight loss.
emotional: Loss of control during eating episodes.
Feelings of guilt, shame, or depression afterward.
physical: Fluctuating weight or progressive weight gain.

biological: Genetic predisposition to obesity or mood disorders
Neurotransmitter dysregulation in dopamine and serotonin systems
environmental: Easy access to highly palatable, calorie-dense foods

impact_on_life.home: Conflict over eating behaviors, secrecy around food.
impact_on_life.school_work: Reduced productivity and concentration due to emotional distress.
impact_on_life.social: Avoidance of social eating situations; isolation.

psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) — gold standard, addresses binge triggers, cognitive distortions, and regular eating patterns.
Interpersonal Psychotherapy (IPT) — focuses on interpersonal triggers and emotional regulation.
Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) — for emotion regulation and distress tolerance.
nutrition_rehabilitation: Structured meal planning to prevent extreme hunger and reduce binge risk.
Dietitian support to normalize eating patterns.
medical_management: Monitor metabolic health, treat comorbid medical conditions.
medications: SSRIs (e.g., fluoxetine, sertraline) for mood/anxiety and reduction in binge frequency.
Topiramate (off-label, may reduce binge frequency and aid weight loss).
lifestyle_interventions: Regular physical activity for health (not as a compensatory behavior).
Sleep hygiene to reduce stress eating.

treatment_goals: Eliminate binge episodes and restore control over eating.
Reduce medical risks associated with BED.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Assuming binge eating is simply 'overeating' without loss of control.
Focus on obesity without assessing for BED behaviors.
overdiagnosis_factors: Misinterpreting emotional eating as meeting full criteria.
Applying diagnosis to night eating syndrome or bulimia nervosa.
warning_signs: Hiding food or eating in secret.
self_help_strategies: Keep a food and mood journal to identify triggers.
Establish regular meal and snack times.
Engage in non-food coping activities for stress.

childhood: Episodes may involve sneaking or hiding food.
Often associated with early weight gain.
adolescence: Increased frequency with stress from school or peer relationships.
Risk of co-occurring depression or anxiety.
adulthood: Episodes tied to work stress, relationships, or life transitions.

real_life_examples: A college student eats large amounts of fast food late at night after stressful exams, then feels intense guilt and skips classes.
A middle-aged office worker binges in secret after arguments at home, leading to weight gain and prediabetes.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek help if you experience recurrent loss of control over eating, significant distress, or health problems related to eating behaviors.

positive_factors: Willingness to engage in structured eating patterns
challenging_factors: Significant weight stigma or repeated dieting failures
